So I suppose, eating the pancreas of an animal, or perhaps a gland that may contain a toxin, or maybe...just maybe we...after many attempts of trial and error of becoming sick from food improperly prepared, during various food renaissances, that that was just stupid, too??
Come on, lol
This is why I stated it to be of a rustic nature. Do you want me to chew your food for you as well?

Idk...although, I agree with you on the probable difficulty of eating this, I also think there is a whole lot of fun in getting to interact with your food on a level such as this. A food like this, should be seen "fun food". Not only does it require you to get your hands a bit oily (hopefully with copious amounts of butter), but you make a dish like this rarely and preferentially with friends. In essence, promoting comraderie and conversation.
As a cook, I understand that most people go out to eat to have everything done for them. But as a cook, I also understand the message represented in rustic cooking. My Nana would of told me to either eat it, or eat shit. It is what it is.
No shit. Like how much do one of those things cost, and what are they made of?

This might not be relevant for a bit, but never trust a puddle. A 1 cm deep puddle looks the same as a 6 in deep pothole filled with water.

I've been biking everyday here for a couple years, and apart from one clearly malicious driver (see rant thread January 2016), one crash that was completely my fault, and occasional eye rolls, I've never had a bad experience on a bike.
Somewhat related, never trust cross traffic to stop just because you know they have a stop sign. I had a not very friendly encounter with a car who basically ran their stop sign whilst I was riding at a good clip (47th and Clinton). I had no time to react and plowed into the side of their SUV. Few broken ribs later, I really wished I had taken their info (I am one that doesn't like to hassle others, if not necessary--I blame my adrenaline in this instance). A fellow cyclist caught it on vid, but I can't seem to find it. I'll update the post if I do.

It really is not so much anger, as it is frustration at how uncompassionate many in this subreddit are. The second homelessness comes up, it's one big circle jerk over-generalizing all homeless as "people who shit on the sidewalks".
I probably worded my original statement rather harshly, but it is still relevant to Portland's changing environment. More so than the occasional person shitting on a sidewalk. Dogs shit on sidewalks, too. And a whole hell of a lot more often too, for that matter.

I'm pretty poor, so costs are pretty important to me.

An increase in more tax dollars; yes..I do agree with this. But, there is also the fact that it will increase everything about living here.
What I would like to see is more proposals in finding a balance. Seeing things in black and white will not get anyone anywhere. It simply promotes angst.
